item.title: Psyllidae spp.
item.dc:creator: triplett
item.description: The first photo shows some lerps and what I assume is a psylid nymph. Psylid nymphs except for the first stage crawlers should not normally be seen but I read that sometimes they move to a different location to feed, which would make sense since the leaf seems to be quite badly damaged. Other photos show what appear to be newly emerged adults on the same red gum sapling. I assume the orange ones (about 2mm long) are female and the tiny black ones (about 0.5mm) male, but this is just a guess they could be something completely different. There were masses of lerps on this sapling and most still had nymphs in them when the photos were taken

item.title: Apiomorpha urnalis, Eucalyptus melliodora
item.dc:creator: triplett
item.description: Female galls on Yellow Box. Counted at least 40 on a 2m high sapling. Almost all straight sided, just a few more bulbous. The longest was 20mm. Bulbous gall in the photo is 16mm long and about 6mm diameter.

item.title: Eucalyptus melliodora, Eurymelops rubrovittata
item.dc:creator: triplett
item.description: Colony of Red-line Gumtree Hoppers at the base of a ca. 7 year old Yellow Box (approx 10cm trunk diameter). There were also a few individuals and pairs dispersed on a low branch. There were no ants in attendance so it appears the bugs are not feeding, but they must be at least preparing to mate. The male in the second photo is holding onto the female with his middle legs while vibrating his front and backs legs, usually not touching the female. Many pairs in the main group were behaving in a similar way with varying degrees of contact. In one pair the male had his hind legs stationary but was stroking the "face" of the female with his front legs.

item.title: Acanthosomatidae spp.
item.dc:creator: triplett
item.description: Seems to be feeding on a Yellow Box leaf. After wading through 500+ Pentatomidae photos on Bowerbird the only match I could find was http://www.bowerbird.org.au/observations/88269. According to the post Acanthosomatidae differs from Pentatomidae in having 2 instead of 3 tarsal segments but I don't think you can see that in my crappy photo.

item.title: Eurymeloides spp.
item.dc:creator: triplett
item.description: Another Gumtree hopper seen last summer on Eucalyptus melliodora but not this summer. I have said genus Eurymeloides due to the two rows of spurs on the hind tibia (see third photo), but does not match any species pictures I can find.

item.title: Eurymeloides spp.
item.dc:creator: triplett
item.description: There were huge numbers of leafhoppers around last summer. Here is a species I still have not been able to ID.

item.title: Poecilometis spp.
item.dc:creator: triplett
item.description: There have been many of these nymphs on the same or adjacent wattle to where the adult shield bug in http://natureshare.org.au/observations/5a80fe82ed2a89def7002062 was seen. Only about 10mm long. The pattern resembles the 5th instar nymph at http://www.brisbaneinsects.com/brisbane_stinkbugs/EucalyptStinkBug3.htm

item.title: Poecilometis spp.
item.dc:creator: triplett
item.description: About 20mm long. One or more of these have been hanging around on the same Black Wattle for a few weeks. Similar to http://www.brisbaneinsects.com/brisbane_stinkbugs/EucalyptStinkBug3.htm

item.title: Bursaria spinosa, Monteithiella humeralis
item.dc:creator: triplett
item.description: Bug about 10mm long. Have not had time to try to id. Before I disturbed it it appeared to be feeding on unripe fruit of Sweet Bursaria (see second photo).

item.title: Eurymelops rubrovittata
item.dc:creator: triplett
item.description: On small Yellow Box (coppice regrowth). Many adults (mostly paired) and nymphs on same tree and another nearby. Closest photographic match I have found on the web is Eurymelops rubrovittata, but this seems to be a different species. Host trees will probably be slashed by Parks Victoria soon as in previous two years. Update: I have added another photo which shows the markings on what I assume to be the female. Since these match other photos on the web (including museum specimens on ala) I have changed the species to Eurymelops rubrovittata.
